title: "UTC Operations Leadership Program"
pros: The UTC Operations Leadership Program (OLP) is a premier leadership program offering 3 rotations; associates take on three roles within manufacturing, quality, and supply chain of three different businesses over two years. The OLP presents excellent functional challenges. Early career leaders are stretched in manufacturing, quality, and supply chain challenges that have direct, significant impact to the businesses. The OLP Associates have full exposure to the business in their roles and through networking and mentoring. You will not find better access to executives throughout the company. The exposure to solving tough problems, strategic leadership guidance, and the future direction of the company is also key to the program’s attractiveness. The responsibility and position of the OLPs leads to enormous leadership growth over the two years. OLPs regularly evaluate their skills and the program strategic places OLPs to stretch their skill gaps. OLPs have to work hard to grow in those areas but leave the role much stronger. OLPs have the support of the program and business to facilitate the moves between businesses, as well. Roles are screened for impact to the business and the business supports the OLPs logistic and financial needs with a comprehensive moving package. The OLPs have numerous opportunities to network in and outside their teams and businesses. The name of the program itself opens doors to supportive executives that give mentoring, both formally through assigned executive mentors, and informally, as OLPs reach out to mentors per their career interests and development needs. At the end of the two years, OLPs are not short on job opportunities. The program is a two year interview with countless opportunities to present to executives and hiring managers. Taking full advantage of the company’s leadership development review boards, the program puts OLPs at the forefront of key hiring needs. OLPs go on to direct their interests and often have multiple opportunities to choose from. The program is overall a great environment to grow operations talent. The OLPs themselves develop a wide support network within their cohort of fellow associates as well as the larger employee network. The program recognizes the challenges OLPs take on, even more than the company’s already strong reward for performance culture. The overall benefits of the program are incalculable. As a former OLP, just recently graduated in 2017 I have no regrets to the challenges and adventures that the program offered me. I would not have been able to springboard my career with the amazing experiences, supportive network, and leadership insights it provided.
cons: The program stretches across all businesses and dozens of sites within the company, each with their own local culture. Some roles, despite the screening, do not fully give the OLPs support initially. Still, a strong OLP finds there’s always work to be done and quickly motivates the site to support them by loading them up with added responsibility by exceeding expectations of performance over and over.

cons: - Eliminated bonus - Work/Life balance is poor - Reactionary, not proactive - Poor mentoring - Poor job growth, unless you move around - Focused on results and results only - Eliminated employee stock purchase plan - Forced furloughs, unpaid - Poor company culture I think people look for good culture, being valued, trained, and moving up the career ladder. With this company I look around at jobs that I would potentially want. What I see are a bunch of managers who work 60-80hr weeks, weekends, etc, they tell everyone below that we MUST meet these numbers and that saturday and sunday are game for work. They force salary employees to take a 2.5% pay reduction and expect that the vacation day after the furlough be worked as we must meet the numbers. They micromanage down to the suppliers, they fly people to hand carry parts as part shortages are rampant. They pay massive expedite fees and ensure that they hit their numbers at no cost. If you need to come in at 6 or 8PM or stay till then, well...we need to hit the numbers. So I look up at these people, these people who run these companies like this, who instill hatred into the workers who once loved their jobs and think to myself, I don't want a single one of these positions, and to think even deeper about it, that UTC drives this culture as these individuals have been promoted to these positions. So they drive numbers, they drive it at the cost of moral, of culture and work life balance. They make you feel insignificant and replaceable, and I am sure everyone is. They even make you one of the gears (people) in their COG. This company doesn't pay all that well, no wonder turn over is high. People celebrate when others get jobs at other companies, somewhat of a weird culture. Another very weird culture is what is being flown down from management. They put a lot of groups in impossible situations. One instance is utilization, and financial targets. With long cycle times they push to meet financial goals so you focus resource efforts to hit those targets, once the month is done you are left with a gap in production because the resources were focused on moving product out the door, they turn around and ask why there is a gap and why utilization is effected Probably because you told us to work 12 hours days sat/sun to move product out the door, how can you not understand the rammifications of doing so, you are sacrificing level loaded production through long assemblies for production numbers, I cannot hit all goals when you tell me goals that directly conflict, catch 22. I cannot simultaneously train and have high utilization at the same time. Progress comes from training and investment, yet you look at numbers and charts and you expect change just because we are tracking them. Large changes come from training and investments, small incremental changes do come from process improvements, but when you hamstring us with part shortages, you screw all your measurements, and the worst of all is our group has no control over it. So being put in these situations is very frustrating for the group and leads to low morale. Would I recommend my daughter to work here, Only if she needed the money, but I would recommend working somewhere else. Keep in mind that UTC owns a lot of sites and each site varies widely. I have worked at a few sites and some are better than others.

The company is trying to fit a blanket one size fits all to everything. all of the ACE structure and standard work, and the new product introduction stuff is very lengthy and convoluted. Its less about engineering work and more about paperwork, charting, bottomline thinking. It claims to be innovative, but its tough to fit in innovation with all the stuff going on. The company doesn't focus at all, its a mess of everything in your face. Constently doing safety improvements all the time, job hazard analysis, ergo stuff, normal work, supervisor/manager stuff, hiring freezes, cutting costs, etc. This is expected to be carried out by the areas supervisors. Some of the decisions made by management turn out to be huge costly mistakes, because UTC views managers as managers. not as technical leaders in the company so they hire those with little experience in the field. They have a hierarchy, managers sit in rooms with windows, those who aren't managers don't. They definitely have a the haves and have nots between the L3 and everything below L4 paygrades. They obviously value education lots but seem not to apply it or retain those that are bright. I really want to like this company, I like some of the people still working here (mind you MANY have left) but its difficult to work for a company where you don't want to move up due to work life balance, marginal pay differences, and stress. It's a very confused company who wants black and white and implements all shades of grey. They value diversity and force rigid standard work on you. They look at metrics and implement plans without understanding the problems. They assign these solutions but the enforcer can't effectively implement without knowing the problems. All I see is one big confusion, it's like upper management has no idea what businesses they own or just purchased.

pros: There are lots of opportunities for movement - many locations within a 30 minute driving area as well as many locations around the world if a move is preferred. title: "Good place to learn...and then move on."
pros: UTRC offers a very wide variety of technical project options to work on; The technical & engineering staff is extraordinary, and among the best in the world; UTRC offers an excellent vantage point into all UTC businesses, and is great place to learn about UTC; The Employee Scholar Program used to be the best in class...now, it's only slightly better than peer companies.
cons: The organization lacks any serious leverage with the business units and constantly struggles with sustaining long term research vision. Programs are started and stopped on short notice in response to funding surges and cut-backs from the BUs. Maximum visibility of funding is 1year for any program; "5-year" roadmaps are annually created...and re-edited. While some process discipline is necessary in any organization, UTRC has taken it to a level that appears to be counter-productive to the "research & innovation" theme. Everything is so rigidly structured that lateral thinking and risk taking happen more as anomalies.

cons: Age is definitely respected in promotion consideration for manager level and above. Very competitive hiring process and credentials may be more important that experience.

title: "Hamiltion in San Diego"

title: "UTC Entry Level Finance Position"

All the companies are market leaders and provide challenging work.
cons: All the busineses are within the manufacturing industry so if you are looking for something other than that, this is not the place. There is really no interaction with consumers or the public. Only business to business/government. UTC also has an aging workforce that have been with the company for many years. This is a good thing which shows loyalty to the company but they are so they are stuck in their ways. It's hard for young workers to adjust and accept that their coworkers and supervisors just are not ready for change.

title: "Content for now but will jump at the first opportunity to get out."
pros: Commitment to furthering education and EH&S are very strong. Work hours are decent for manufacturing outfits. Salaried workforce is often eligible for at least 1X overtime pay.
cons: Firm conducts regular employee surveys, promises to take action on shortcomings, and seemingly never does. Support for personal growth is at odds with a general lack of advancement opportunity. Very rarely do I observe people promoted from within and when I do, it tends to be those in mid to upper management. New hires are often brought in from the outside and offered top level positions that appear out of thin air. Genuine continuous improvement at this company is still in its infancy. ACE could be so much more but right now its bark is far worse than its bite. Management doesn't support it enough. I question sometimes if they even understand it. Annual review process is a box check. I performed better one year than another, by the numbers, yet still received a lower overall score.

title: "UTC"
pros: The Technical capability of UTC is extremely strong, excellent environment to learn corporate politics. Tremendous latitude allowed employees to make major errors.
cons: It appears 200,000 plus employees is a little excessive and would make for unmanageable organization. Not enough monies expended on Research and Development.

title: "Learn, then Leave If Necessary..."
pros: Development if technical and leadership skills. Professional workforce and great educational opportunities.
cons: Depending on group and division, one can be placed on a very slow career path. It's best to pursue other opportunities with UTC after about 3-5 years.

title: "Great company and projects.  Project planning methods need upgrades."
pros: Leading edge products that are actually helping the USA and the world. Efficient aircraft engines reduce our use of fossil fuels and Fuel cells let us run mass transit on clean hydrogen. The company has a fairly flat management hierarchy, which means that access to management is good. The work environment is professional without being stuffy.
cons: Union rules and inconsistency of qualities of workers assigned make it hard to manage engineering projects. Management often allows projects, especially software to begin without nailing down the end customer requirements, which results in the software team having to code to "a move target" and therefore always being late because the estimates the team gave were based on fixed requirements. Flat hierarchy means less positions to move up into, so after a few years it makes sense to move on.

title: "Perhaps we should call ourselves disparate technologies"
pros: I work for a division of Pratt & Whitney which is one of the major business units of UTC. We were purchased from the Boeing Company a little less than 3.5 years ago. Before that, we were owned by Rockwell International. I have worked for these three major multi-national corporations essentially without changing desks. Of the three, UTC is the second best. Regardless, I get to work on - among other things - rocket engines and I get to be part of hurling humans into space. What could be bad about that? UTC has, over all, really exciting products to be working on and I get to work on what I consider some of the most exciting. That's reason enough for me. Overall, as well, the pay and benefits aren't all that bad and the corporation tries to be responsible and respectful.
cons: UTC is very hierarchical and backward-looking when it comes to its management style. The company is top-heavy with attorneys, overly protective of Intellectual Property, and verges on the paranoid with respect to intranet and Internet security. There is little trust displayed in how the corporation protects those interests it seems to divorce from the interests of its employees. They have also moved to outsource virtually all of their information technology assets. This appears to be unfortunate in light of the seismic changes occurring in web-based (Internet or intranet) services and the design principles behind them - sometimes referred to as Web 2.0. My experience is that very few people involved in IT (especially the "leadership") have little idea of what's going on in the outside world that is driving the development of web-based services. So . . . when it comes to information technology as it is used in support of business processes and innovation, I would aver that United Technologies is well behind the curve and is digging itself a hole that may be hard to climb out of someday; maybe soon.

title: "Run. Away. Now."
pros: Employee scholarship program - free tuition, regardless of study area.
cons: Incompetent middle management. Recently, there have been many lay-offs and movements of senior managers. Middle management has been aware of them, but failed to communicate any information to us. In fact, they herded us into a room and demanded to know what rumors we'd heard about the reorganization (while indicating that they knew everything and would not tell us about it). Low recognition of staff. One of the products released this year had been under the guidance of someone who was laid off. The new manager came in and took all the kudos for the new product, with no indication that it had, in fact, been 90% completed by the previous team (including people still in the organization).

title: "UTC Overall a good place.  A lot depends on business unit and your department."
pros: Tuition reimbursement for taking any college level class. Graduation Gift ($10,000) for completing a degree using tuition reimbursement (employee scholar program). Paid time off (up to 3 hours per week) for class work plus all textbooks for classes paid for. Casual dress code and relaxed atmosphere with many great people. Flexible work hours. Christmas shutdown from Christmas Eve to new year day off.
cons: Lower pay compared to other companies in the area. Significant pay differences within different business units for similar work. Classic big company with lots of management layers and bureaucracy. IT services outsourced to CSC Corporation and their (CSC) service is non-existent and their policies are fit for company with main frames. Takes 7 years of service to get 3 weeks of vacation. Most company sponsored functions (such as company picnics) tied to united way fundraising and they nickel and dime you for everything (so it really is not company sponsored). Unionized hourly employees have no real incentive to do a good job on their work and sometimes difficult to work with.

title: "UTC: Join for job security not for growth or innovation"
pros: Job security! UTC competes with the like of GE, Honeywell, Ingersoll Rand, etc. Out of the group UTC has diversified very effectively yet at the sametime maintained synergy between it's 7 units. As a result, UTC has had very few job lay-offs in the last 10 years. Not to mention high return on investment for the shareholders. UTC has also been very effective in using low cost outsourcing companies. This has not only lowered product development cost but also mitigates the risk of mass lay-offs. UTC has one of the best continuing education program imaginable. Company pays full tuition and books regardless of the type of degree you are pursuing as long as its at an accredited college or university. For example, an engineer can get a law degree with no questions asked by your immediate manager, director, HR, or any one. No contracts, no stipulations, no catch whatsover. Once you receive your degree the company also gives a $10k stock award vested right away!!! Once again, no contracts, no stipulations, no catch attached to the stock award.
cons: Very low salary and benefits. Most UTC units (Otis, Pratt & Whitney, Sikorsky, Career, UTC Power) are based out of Connecticut, which has very cost of living. Pay and salaries on the other hand are below average across the board. UTC abolished performance based bonus several years ago. During three year period between 2000-2002, Pratt and Whitney unit did not give out raises, citing difficult economic conditions. Later on the company report record profits for years 2001 and 2002, making it's CEO George David the highest paid CEO in the nation in 2002 and 2003 at $60 million and $80 million respectively. Company didn't make up for it to the employees in the following years either as was evident by a mere 3% raise in 2003 and 2004 and 3.5% thereafter. UTC does provides 401k matching at a rate of 3.6% on the first 6% only. This is on the extreme lower end of the spectrum. Furthermore, UTC does not have a Employee Stock Purchase program either. Finally, increase in out of pocket cost of healthcare (premiums plus deductables) has out-paced cost of living increase by a factor of 2. Performance raises on the other hand have never topped 3.5%. Most UTC business units are mired with bureaucracy at all levels. This results in monumental levels of inefficiency which in turn rears its ugly head in the form of low job satisfaction and high level of personal and professional frustrations. Other businesses in the area who are often in the position to recruit UTC employees are extremely aware of UTC's bureaucratic work culture and are cautious in hiring ex-UTC employees. Annual survey conducted internally by UTC have consistently revealed low job satisfaction level compared to industry and nationwide averages. UTC also scores poorly in the area of pay and benefits.

There is also good opportunity for experiencing different products and businesses among its many divisions if you're flexible enough. You will work with some of the most intelligent professionals around in nearly every job function and level.
cons: Nepotism is the norm in recognition and advancement so if you are not related to, or life long friends with an executive "in the loop" promotional opportunities will be limited. You will still find exciting, leading edge technology here but everything is driven by shareholder profit and the associated executive salaries. The investments in long term technology advancement, product performance, and sense of community responsibility the company was long known for are now clearly secondary to cost reduction and share price priorities.

title: "Great place to work and grow."
pros: Very honest and ethical approach to business.
cons: Workload demands are very great.

title: "Fantastic place to work in"
pros: Dynamic business and management. Currently the market leader.
cons: Hard work. Stress but fulfilling

title: "Started Out Great but Now I Feel I Am Going Nowhere"
pros: The Employee Scholarship Program is great and allows you to get your degree(s). That's about the only great thing.
cons: Benefits are horrendous, company only concerned about saving money and not what the employees needs are. Pay scales seem a bit off and freezing merit raises was unjust considering upper management still made their bonuses.

title: "A Grind"
pros: Employee Scholar Program, Fortune 50 experience, broad exposure to industry, easy to develop professionally, paid week off at the end of the year without a hit to your vacation (shut down)
cons: Understaffed, limited/non-existent growth opportunities, no diversity in management (tall, white males), no recognition of performance, over-reliance on temporary and contract workers

title: "Ready to Move Up"
pros: Excellent Benefits; Opportunity for Growth and Promotions; Tuition for College; Respected Company in the local area; Numerous locations all around the world; Leading Company for aviation.
cons: Due to the economy being so fragile, I really can't think of any reason not to be employed with United Technologies or any other company to maintain a job.

title: "Products and Processes getting better, but morale very low."
pros: - Good benefits, 401 (k) matching, scholarship program, health, etc. - In my limited experience with them, I have been impressed with senior management. They are more right than wrong as far as the direction they're taking Carrier (can't say much about the other units).
cons: - Comp below average starting out and salary freeze (which has only thawed very little) has made that worse. - Very unsatisfied with managers of my particular division (small division, won't name here). At least for my division, management has an extreme defensive "silo" mentality. Many times they have made decisions or "planned" with assumptions completely detached from how work is actually done. Management is either completely hands off, with no direction or accountability to workers, or micromanages and gives the end employee zero freedom. Either way is ultimately unsatisfying. - Division's management has a very 1950's mentality about workers, we're here to punch a clock and not ask questions. Well, after a few years here I could go on and on. I'll just say it's not me, morale is extremely low and most everybody is skeptical of our immediate management. It is hard to have motivation to improve processes when there is no reward for doing so and management will often shout down your recommendation anyway. Financial results are doing alright right now, but I can see customer satisfaction is declining due to poor management and not enough capacity to meet deadlines we promise.

title: "Carrier"
pros: It is an excellent company to show on your resume. Learn to deal with management reveiws
cons: Company does not promote career development. Poor reconginition of employee loyalty. Willing to let experienced professionals leave to replace with less experienced professionals at a higher compensation level

title: "Lead lean efforts for the UTC operating system, ACE."

title: "Not bad overall"
pros: Generous Employee Scholar Program including paid time off for school, promotion from within, large variety of functions, access to many different training courses (both technical and soft skills), direct management supportive
cons: Cost of living for the area, many areas understaffed, most employees work 45-50 hour work weeks, union presence is very strong against salaried positions

title: "Good Experience Opportunity"
pros: UTC has an extensive standard work approach. IF you want to learn tools you've not yet mastered, this could be the place.
cons: Politics are intense; if you are not connected, you don't exist. Good work, per-se is not recognized as much as who you know.

title: "Balancing the standard work vs. innovation"
pros: UTC has established standard work and a strong infrastructure to ensure that the tribal knowledge is collected and maintained. There is extensive availability of training opportunities not only to support your current work efforts but you own personal growth. There is a extensive amount of effort in educating the workforce on business ethics and changing the employees view of supporting the customer so that they only want your product.
cons: There is a tendency to focus on all the tools put in place on not on the objective of using the tools. The standard tools were intended to make us more efficient, give us a place to go to understand and simplify what needs to be done and make sure that from one business unit to another we are working in the same manner. Instead maintaining the tools and evaluating the tools have become more and more of the job. People worry more about the tool being used correctly then the output of the tool.

title: "A good company that won't make you rich"
pros: UTC is a old fashion company that is conservatively managed. The company has very good cash flow and stable over decades. It is not affected so much by the down turn. It also has very good employee education program that pays a decent amount of tuition.
cons: Somewhat lack opportunities for young employees. Politics is real. Pay is not good for some professionals because UTC pay standard may be benchmarked against mechanical engineers, which do not get paid most.

title: "Great company for stable career.  Top performers not rewarded with top compensation."
pros: UTC has a great long term benefits program and its wide range of products and services provides a stable career if you are willing to relocate.
cons: Publicly traded company is always looking for more to meet Wall Street Expectations. However, when you provide more, the top performers are not properly rewarded or provided with career development opportunities. It may be you are just a "number" when it comes to compensation. Management is competent and stock will do well, but it you are the top of your trade, you may do better with a competitor company or another industry.

title: "Blue Chip firm that misses on the softer stuff"
pros: Wide variety of business issues Ability to work on projects of diverse geographic scope Opportunity to work with cutting edge technology
cons: highly bureaucratic environment human capital management activities are very poor internal rotational activities or initiatives are almost nonexistent, little career flexibility
